title: SARS-CoV-2 proteome microarray for COVID-19 patient sera profiling
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of proteins
Timing: 7 days
Besides the E. coli expression system, to cover the proteome of SARS-CoV-2 as complete as possible, and to obtain proteins with post-translational modifications (PTM), especially glycosylation, recombinant SARS-CoV-2 proteins were also produced using yeast cell-free systems or mammalian cell expression systems from a variety of commercial sources. Here we describe the affinity purification procedure (key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]).
The genes synthesized by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai, China) were cloned into pET32a or pGEX-4T-1 vector and transformed into E. coli BL21 strain. Express the recombinant proteins in E. coli BL21 by growing cells in 200 mL LB medium to an A600 of 0.6 at 37°C.
Induce protein expression. Add 0.2 mM isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactoside (IPTG) before incubating cells for 16 h at 16°C.
Prepare and re-suspend the cell pellets in lysis buffer, and lyse by a high-pressure cell cracker.
Centrifuge the Cell lysates at 12,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C.
Affinity purification. Purify the supernatants with Ni2+ Sepharose beads, then wash with lysis buffer and elute with buffer containing 10% glycerol, 50 mM Tris-HCl pH8.0, 500 mM NaCl and 300 mM imidazole.
Verify the purified proteins by SDS-PAGE followed by western blotting using an anti-His antibody and Coomassie brilliant blue staining (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).

(D) The correlations of the overall IgG and IgM signal intensities between two repeats probed with the same serum.
(E) Construction of an antibody response landscape against SARS-CoV-2 proteome (Li et al., 2021c[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).

(H) The 16-well chamber.
Some of recombinant SARS-CoV-2 protein were also collected from commercial sources (please see the key resources table[href=https://www.wicell.org#key-resources-table]).
Note: Please refer to Jiang et al. (2020)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2] for more details.
Protein microarray fabrication
Timing: 2 days
High quality microarray is essential to ensure the final results. The detailed process of fabricating the microarray is as follows.
Transfer the proteins and controls to a 384-well plate.
Dilute the proteins and controls with Printing buffer (1× PBS with 25% glycerol) to a final concentration of 0.3 mg/mL.
Add the proteins into the predetermined wells of a 384-well plate. For the SARS-CoV-2 proteome, the layout of the array was set as 32 × 6 features, each protein was repeated for 3 spots (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B). The appropriate volume range for each well is 10 μL–50 μL.
Note: the volume range varies among different types of 384-well plates.
After adding the protein samples, centrifuge the 384-well plate at 800 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Note: the plate with protein samples could be stored at −80°C for at least one year.

Protein printing on microarray slide.
Use the printer (Super Marathon) to print the proteins on to the PATH substrate slides according to the manufacturer’s instruction.
Note: The website of the printer: https://www.arrayjet.co.uk/instruments/printers-in-detail[href=https://www.arrayjet.co.uk/instruments/printers-in-detail].
Incubate the microarrays at 4°C with humidity less than 50% overnight (over 12 h) for complete immobilization of proteins on the microarray.
Put the slides into the dedicated slide box (5 or 1 slide(s) per box), seal the box with Parafilm and store the box at −80°C.
GAL (GenePix Array List) file generation.
Create an Excel file and mark the position of samples on the 384-well plate.

Create GAL file using the printer software (Marathon V 2.2).
Microarray quality evaluation. The purpose of this step is to detect whether all proteins are printed on the slides and whether the immobilized proteins are still active, so as to ensure that the subsequent sera profiling can be carried out.
Blocking.
Take out the microarrays from −80°C and leave them at 4°C for 30 min, then transfer them to room temperature for 15 min to enable temperature equilibrium.
Critical: for PATH substrates, pay attention to sealing in the process of rewarming, avoid condensation on the slide surface.
Prepare the blocking buffer (1× PBS with 3% BSA), add 30 mL blocking buffer to a container and kept at 25°C.
Face down the microarray and immerse the barcode side into blocking buffer, while keep the other side out, then slowly lay down the microarray until it is completely immersed into the buffer. Gently shake the microarray to make sure the bubbles on the microarray surface are driven out, turn over the microarray and immerse it into buffer.
Note: the whole process of this step should be slow and take at least 1.5 min to avoid trailing effect on the microarray.

Shake the microarrays at 20–30 rpm/min on a shaker for 3 h at 25°C.
Wash and dry the microarrays.
Discard the blocking buffer. Add 20–30 mL 1× PBS into the container, keep shaking (20–30 rpm) for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the PBS buffer. Add 20–30 mL 0.2× PBS into the container, keep shaking (20–30 rpm) for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the PBS buffer. Add 20–30 mL ddH2O into the container, keep shaking (20–30 rpm) for 5 min at 25°C.
Put the microarrays into the slide centrifuge SlideWashTM 8 with default parameters. Centrifuge the microarrays at 500 × g for 1–2 min to dry them.
Note: the dried microarrays can be stored at 4°C in a sealed box.
Antibody incubation.
Prepare incubation buffer. Dilute the Anti-His antibody at 1:5000 in PBST buffer (0.1% Tween 20 in 1× PBS buffer).
Add 3 mL incubation buffer into the microarray slide container. Shake the container at 4°C and 20–30 rpm for 12 h.
Discard the incubation buffer. Add 5 mL PBST buffer and shake at 25°C for 5 min. Repeat this step for 3 times.
Secondary antibody incubation.
Dilute Cy5 labeled Anti-Rabbit secondary antibody at a ratio of 1:1000 in PBST buffer.
Add the secondary antibody into the microarray slide container, shake at 25°C for 1 h.
Discard the incubation buffer. Add 5 mL PBST buffer and shake at 25°C for 5 min. Repeat this step for 3 times.
Dry the microarrays by centrifugation with SlideWashTM 8. Centrifuge the microarrays at 500 × g for 1–2 min.
Microarray scanning
Turn on the microarray scanner Genepix 4200A and warm up for 15 min.

Scan the microarray at both 532 nm (IgG) and 635 nm (IgM) channel. Recommended scanning parameters: 95% power, PMT 200-300. However, the optimal scanning parameters should be adjusted according to the overall signal intensity.
After scanning is completed, save the two images as a single TIF file (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Serum profiling
Timing: 2 days
Blocking. This step is same as the blocking step of quality evaluation.
Sera sample preparation. Centrifuge the tube with sera at 12,000 × g at 4°C for 20 min. Dilute the sera in incubation buffer which contains 1% BSA and 0.1% Tween 20 in 1× PBS (1:200).
Sample incubation.
Install a 16-well chamber on the microarray to physically separate the subarrays.
Dilute the sera sample and the positive control at a ratio of 1:200 with incubation buffer (1× PBS with 0.1% tween-20 and 1% BSA). (To our experience, the dilution could range from 1:50 to 1:1000, however, to balance foreground and background, 1:200 is the best dilution for serum profiling on protein microarray. Thus, in the COVID-19 study, we empirically chose 1:200).
Add 200 μL diluted serum sample to each subarray. For each microarray, the last two subarrays are added with incubation buffer (1% BSA in PBST) and the positive sera sample as blank control and positive control, respectively. The blank control is to monitor unexpected contaminations.
Incubate the microarrays at room temperature (25°C) for 2 h.
Note: Immediately record the sample number, including the block position and the slide number.
Wash the microarrays.
Remove the sera from each subarray with a multichannel pipette, add 200 μL wash buffer (1× PBS with 0.1% tween-20), and pipette up and down for 10 times.
Repeat the above step twice.

Uninstall the 16-well chamber, place the microarrays in a container with ∼30 mL wash buffer. Keep the container on a shaker (90–100 rpm) at room temperature (25°C) for 10 min. Repeat this step twice.
Note: Do not leave the surface of the slide dry.
Secondary antibody incubation
Dilute the Cy3 labeled anti-Human IgG and Alexa Fluor 647 (635 nm excitation) labeled anti-Human IgM secondary antibody (1: 1000) with incubation buffer.
Discard the Wash buffer from the container and add 15 mL diluted secondary antibodies.
Keep the container on a shaker (20–30 rpm) for 1 h at room temperature (25°C). Keep the microarrays shielded from light.
Note: 1) if only one microarray is used, a smaller container would be suggested with a smaller incubation volume. 2) Depending on the isotypes of antibody of interest, multiple isotypes could be detected simultaneously, only if the isotype specific fluorescence labeled secondary antibodies are available and compatible with the microarray scanner.
Wash and dry.
Remove the solution from the container and add 30 mL Wash buffer. Keep the container at room temperature (25°C) and shake for 90–100 rpm on a shaker for 10 min. Repeat this step for three times.
Wash the slide with ddH2O for 10 min, and rinse with ddH2O for 10 s.
Dry the slide by centrifugation.
Note: From step 15 on, the slides should be kept under dark.
Microarray scanning.
Turn on the microarray scanner Genepix 4200A and warm up for 15 min.
Scan the microarray at 532 nm (IgG) and 635 nm (IgM) channel. Recommended scanning parameters: 95% power, PMT 200-300. However, the optimal scanning parameters should be adjusted according to the overall signal intensity.
After scanning is completed, save the result as one single TIF file (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).

Critical: The same scanning parameters should be applied to the microarrays in the same experiment.
Critical: Avoid scratching on microarray surface in any way during the whole process.
Microarray data processing
Timing: 1 day
Quantitative signal intensity of each protein indicates the antibody response of one serum sample, which can be acquired by transforming the fluorescence intensity of each spot in the microarray image to digital signal, i. e., the microarray data extraction. The data are normalized to calibrate the differences among different microarrays.
Extract microarray data.
The software Genepix 6.0 enables automatic alignment. Using the GAL file (step 10) to align the features of the microarray image, before extract the data, it is necessary to double check the aligned features and adjust the incorrectly aligned features.
Click the “analysis” button to extract the data of all features and generate a GPR file (raw data) for each microarray.
Calculate signal intensity.
Calculate signal intensity for each feature: subtract Foreground Median (F median) with Background Median (B median). IgG (532 nm channel) and IgM (635 nm channel) are calculated separately.
Calculate the average of the triplicates of each protein in the same subarray.
Normalization among microarrays. Use the data of block #14 in each slide (the positive sera sample) to calculate the normalization factor (Factor N) for each microarray. IgG (532 nm channel) and IgM (635 nm channel) are calculated separately.
Exclude the features with low signal intensity (< 300).
With the data of block #14 of all microarrays, calculate the overall average signal intensity for each protein (without the controls) to create a reference data set.
Calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient between the reference data set and each data set of block #14. Exclude the spots which away from the diagonal line when the coefficient is less than 0.98.

Calculate the Factor N for each using the following function in Excel software: LINEST (Y, X i, FALSE), where the Y is the reference data set, the X i is the data of block #14 from slide i , and FALSE means to make the constant term equal to 0.
For each slide, all the signal intensities are normalized by multiplying the corresponding Factor N.
